awd_titl_txt: RAPID: STEM faculty support to address impacts from COVID-19 on Tribal Colleges and Universities Program institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education, and sustainability of capacity gains is significantly enhanced by retaining the talent of credentialed STEM faculty. This project aligns directly with that goal.

The coronavirus pandemic of 2020-2021 caused major disruptions to institutions of higher education. However, for tribal colleges and universities, whose core operating funds are directly aligned with student enrollment, drops in enrollment equate to loss of funding. To mitigate against detrimental effects on STEM instructional capacity, this award will support the position of one full-time STEM faculty member, as well as other resources to maintain Red Lake Nation College’s STEM program as it recovers from the impact of the pandemic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project is to reduce COVID-19 pandemic-related negative impacts on Red Lake Nation College (RLNC) STEM instructional and programming capacity by supporting the salary and professional development of one full-time STEM faculty member teaching mathematics and technology. Specifically, the objectives included supporting the salary and benefits for one mathematics and technology faculty and providing professional development opportunities for that faculty member.

Funding supported one year of salary and benefits for Red Lake Nation College Mathematics Instructor Jeffery Jones, providing helpful support for maintaining STEM faculty during the COVID-19 pandemic.

For professional development, Mr. Jones also took five graduate courses to complete a Graduate Certificate in Information Technology in Application Development from Elmhurst University. The five courses were: MIT 510 Database Management and Data Warehousing, MIT 550 Computer Security and Risk Management, MIT 543 Web Application Development, MIT 545 Mobile Application Development, and MBA 509 Project Management

In addition, Mr. Jones attended the Minnesota Council of Teachers of Mathematics Conference in April 2023, where he participated in many relevant math education sessions and networking opportunities.

This funding greatly assisted in supporting Red Lake Nation College STEM faculty and mathematics and technology course offerings during the financial challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/24/2024
Modified by: Lane Azure
